Dr. Lecter, I've brought an affidavit  guaranteeing your new rights... You'll  want to read it before I sign.
He assistant unsnaps his briefcase, reaches for the form.

I won't waste your time and  Catherine's time bargaining for petty  privileges. Clarice Starling and  that awful Jack Crawford have wasted  far too much already. I only pray  they haven't doomed the poor girl...  Let me help you now, and I'll trust  you when it's all over.
You have my word. Paul?
Krendler raises a pad, poised to take notes.

Buffalo Bill's real name is William  Rubin. I met him just once. He was  referred to me in April or May, 1980,  by my patient Benjamin Raspail. They  were lovers, but Raspail had become  very frightened. Apparently Rubin  had murdered a transient, and - done  things with the skin. He thought if  I could cure Billy, then Billy'd be  safe from the police, and he's be  safe from Billy... Obviously, he was  wrong.
We need his address, a physical descr-
Did you nurse Catherine?
(pause; startled) What...?
Did you breast-feed her?
He flicks his tongue obscenely.
You son-of-a -
The Senator stills him with a hand. She is trembling.
Yes... I did.

Toughened your nipples, didn't it...? (a beat; then rapidly,  bored) Six foot one, strongly built, about  190 pounds. Hair brown, eyes pale  blue. He'd be about 35 now. He said  he lived in Philadelphia, but may  have lied. That's really all I can  remember, Senator - but if I think  of any more, I'll let you know.
(to the others) Let's go with it.
They start towards the car, but he calls out, stopping he
Senator Martin...! You can't trust  Jack Crawford or Clarice Starling.  It's such a game with these people.  They're determined to get the arrest  for themselves. The "collar," I think  they say.
Thank you, Doctor. I'll keep it in  mind.
Oh, and Senator...? Love you suit.
CLOSE ON scraps of food - peas, chicken bones - lying on cement floor of the pit, near the foil tray of a TV dinne
(muttering, feisty) Close enough to fuck is close enough  to fight...
is hunched over in concentration. The plastic toilet buck is on her lap, and she has yanked down its cotton string.
Get my legs round your neck, you  goddamn creep, I'll send you home to  Jesus...
are tying a chicken bone to the bucket's handle, where it meets the string. The other end of the string is tied to wrist.
gathers the coiled string in one hand, and swings the buc by its handle, calculating this distance up to the baseme floor.
Okay, Precious. Time for a treat...
She hurls the bucket upwards.

head_text.subj: AT THE LIP OF THE OUBLIETTE

text: the bucket sails out, bounces LOUDLY, then falls back ins
who is elsewhere in the basement, worrying a toy. She coc an ear, making a low GROWL, then sets off to investigate.
Catherine swings the bucket again, trying another cast.
two feet beyond the pit's edge, rolls a bit, stops.
then pauses, staring curiously towards...
the enticing chicken bone, six feet away. It twitches as  Catherine tugs on the string, edging the bucket back towa the pit. Precious with her tail wagging, BARKS - greedy but suspic
staring upwards, pulls again, even so gently, at the stri
(softly) Preeeeecious...! C'mon, boy, nice  yummy bone... c'mon, you little  shit...

edges reluctantly closer... then suddenly rushes in, seiz the bone in her teeth. She tries to run away with it, but Catherine is pulling her towards the hole, working her li a hooked fish. Her toenails scrabble as she tries to stop
stares desperately, unable to see how she's doing.
Hang on, boy... hang on...

still fights for the bone, GROWLING, as the bucket rocks  precariously on the edge of the pit. A long, seesaw battl until finally, when one of her forelegs slips momentarily into the hole, she panics and lets go. The bucket flops o the edge.
crouches, covering her head as the bucket bounces off her
Nooooo...!
furious, BARKS down at her, then trots away in disgust.
as she sinks to the cold cement. She slaps aside the foil tray, the scraps of food, sobbing in utter despair...

CLOSE ON a framed photo of Sen. Martin and Catherine, hel in Clarice's cotton-gloved hands. Powdered fingerprints o the glass. Clarice glances up from the photo, smiles disarmingly at A young STATE TROOPER sitting in Catherine's easy chair. smiles back at her, then relaxes, returns to his newspape He also wears gloves.

Clarice closes the refrigerator door, glances around. A big REEL-TO-REEL TAPE RECORDER has been set up on the  breakfast counter, attached to Catherine's phone. Two new red phones are hooked up as well.
Clarice slides open the medicine cabinet's mirror, looks  inside. She reaches in, pokes carefully amongst the lotio
A ceiling hatch bangs open, sending up dust clouds. Clari lit from underneath, pokes her head through, looking arou
Flat on her back, Clarice wriggles out from under Catheri bed. She sits up, brushing dust from her face and hair.

CLOSE ON an open, multi-tiered jewelry box, resting atop bureau, as Clarice's fingers pick through costume jewelry Clarice closes the box, and is just turning away when a f suddenly looms INTO SHOT, giving her a bad start; she cri out softly. Senator Martin is revealed, staring at her suspiciously.
Who are you, please? I thought the  police were through in here.
I'm Clarice Starling, Senator. FBI.
(softly, very angry) Clarice Starling... (calls out) Paul? Would you come in here,  please...?
Krendler enters from the hallway, looks at Clarice.

Miss Starling, you may know the Deputy  Attorney General, Mr. Krendler. Paul,  this is the trainee that Jack Crawford  sent to Lecter... She lied to him,  pretending to have my authority, and  thus jeopardized this entire  investigation. Now she has the further  gall to invade my daughter's privacy,  again without permission. If her  little games have killed my baby...
Overcome, she hurries from the room. Krendler shuts the d behind her, points sternly at Clarice.
You're out of line, Starling, and  you're off this case. Back to  Quantico.
Sir, Mr. Crawford instructed me -

Your instructions are what I'm giving  you now. Jack Crawford answers to  the Director, and the Director answers  to me. My God, Crawford's losing  it...! He shouldn't even be on this,  with his wife sick as she is... How  the hell did you get in here, anyway?  He gave you - what? Some kind of  special ID? Let's have it.
(stubbornly) I need the ID to fly with my gun.  The gun belongs in Quantico.
Gun. Jesus. Turn in the ID as soon  as you get back. The gun, too. Be on  the next plane, Starling, there's  one in 90 minutes.
Clarice, burning, starts for the door, then turns back.
Mr. Krendler... Dr. Lecter trusts  me. Or at least, he used to. If I  could just -
Lecter has already named Buffalo  Bill.
Clarice reacts, surprised. Krendler takes a folded comput sheet from his pocket, shoves it at her. She takes it, re

He gave us a perfectly good  description, and we're on it now, so  we won't be needing your little  novelty act any longer - or his,  either. He's under close guard at  the courthouse, pending a prison  transfer. The next plane, Officer.
Sir, doesn't this "William Rubin"  strike you as - I don't know - kind  of vague?
Krendler moves in very close to her, pale with anger.
Do you need a police escort, Starling?  Or do you think you can find the  airport by yourself?
Yes sir. I can find it by myself.

The old courthouse is a massive Gothic stronghold, with a armada of police cruisers parked at the curb. Clarice climbs from her rented car, SLAMMING the door ang Holding a rolled-up pile of papers - Dr. Lecter's drawing she starts determinedly up the steps. A nearby commotion  makes her pause. Dr. Frederick Chilton in a sea of interviewers and mini-c is preening grandly.  Clarice carefully avoiding his gaze, slips up the steps a inside.
SGT. TATE, a Memphis policeman, is studying Clarice's ID. looks up at her from his command desk, a bit doubtfully.
Are you with Mr. Krendler's people?
I just left him.
Access to Lecter is strictly limited.  We've been getting death threats. (hesitates again) Log in, and check your weapon.
He picks up a phone, murmurs into it. As he does so, Clar glances around this main ground floor lobby.
The building looks like an armed fort. Cops with shotguns guard the front door, both ends of the hall, the foot of stairs, the single elevator. More of them are coming and  going.
Shoot, we haven't had this kinda  security since the President came  through town...
Clarice and OFFICER MURRAY, a young patrolman, ride up in old-fashioned, CREAKING, metal-cage elevator. He is excit
Every cop in Tennessee wants a look  at this guy. 'Sit true what they're  sayin' - he's some kinda vampire?
(beat) I don't have a name for what he is.
Pembry, at a desk by the door, looks up from examining th unrolled pile of Dr. Lecter's drawings.
You know the rules, ma'am?
Yes, Officer Pembry. I've questioned  him before.
He waves her on her way, but retains the drawings for now
as she crosses the big, spare, white octagonal room. A  massive, temporary iron cage has been installed; Officer  Boyle sits facing its barred door. He rises, nods, moving away to allow her privacy.

a cot and a small table, each bolted to the floor, and a  flimsy paper screen, hiding a toilet. Dr. Lecter sits at table, his back to her, studying the Buffalo Bill case fi He now wears a green prison jumpsuit. A small cassette pl is chained to the steel table.
(without turning) Good afternoon, Clarice.
She stops at a striped police barricade, before his bars.
I thought you might want your drawings  back... Just until you get your view.
How very thoughtful... Or did Crawford send you here for one last wheedle -  before you're both booted off the  case?
Nobody sent me. I came on my own.
He spins in his swivel chair, stops neatly. A coy smile.
People will say we're in love. (beat) Pity you tried to fool me, isn't it?  Pity for poor Catherine. Tick-tock...
He spins again in his chair, playfully.
as she circles the cage, trying to keep his face in sight
Dr. Lecter, you find out everything.  You couldn't have talked with this  "William Rubin", even once, and come  out knowing so little about him...  You made him up, didn't you?
Clarice... you're hardly in a position  to accuse me of lying.
I think you were telling me the truth  in Baltimore - or starting to. Tell  me the rest now.
I've studied the case file, have  you...? Everything you need to find  him is right in these pages. Whatever  his name is.
Then tell me how.
First principles, Clarice. Simplicity.  Read Marcus Aurelius. Of each  particular thing, ask: What is it,  in itself, what is its nature...?  What does he do, this man you seek?
He kills w-
(sharply, as he stops) No! That's incidental.
CLOSE ANGLE - TWO SHOT as he rises, pained by her ignoran and crosses to the bars.
What is the first and principal thing  he does, what need does he serve by  killing?
Anger, social resentment, sexual  frus-
No, he covets. That's his nature.  And how do we begin to covet, Clarice?  Do we seek out things to covet? Make  an effort to answer.
No. We just -
No. Precisely. We begin by coveting  what we see every day. Don't you  feel eyes moving over your body,  Clarice? I hardly see how you  couldn't. And don't your eyes move  over the things you want?
All right, then tell me how -
No. It's your turn to tell me,  Clarice. You don't have any more  vacations to sell, on Anthrax Island.  Why did you run away from that ranch?
Dr. Lecter, when there's time I'll -
We don't reckon time the same way,  Clarice. This is all the time you'll  ever have.
Later, listen, I'll -
I'll listen now. After your father's  murder, you were orphaned. You were  ten years old. You went to live with  cousins, on a sheep and horse ranch  in Montana. And - ?
And - one morning I just - ran away...
She turns from him. He presses closer, gripping the bars.
Not "just," Clarice. What set you  off? You started what time?
Early. Still dark.
Then something woke you. What? Did  you dream...? What was it?

The 10-year old Clarice sits up abruptly in her bed,  frightened. She is in a Montana ranch house; it almost da Strange, fearful shadows on her ceiling and walls... a wi partly fogged by the cold; eerie brightness outside.
I heard a strange sound...
What was it?
crosses to the window in her nightgown, rubs the glass.
I didn't know. I went to look...

Shadowy men, ranch hands, are moving in and out of a near barn, carrying mysterious bundles. The mens' breath is  steaming... A refrigerated truck idles nearby, its engine adding more steam. A strange, almost surrealistic scene..
Screaming! Some kind of - screaming.  Like a child's voice...
is terrified; she covers her ears.
What did you do?
Got dressed without turning on the  light. I went downstairs... outside...

in her winter coat, slips noiselessly towards the open ba door. She ducks into the shadows to avoid a ranch hand, w passes her with a squirming bundle of some kind. He goes  into the barn, and she edges after him reluctantly.
I crept up to the barn... I was so  scared to look inside - but I had  to...
as the open doorway LOOMS CLOSER... Bright lights inside, straw bales, the edges of stalls, then moving figures...
And what did you see, Clarice?
is held down on a table by two ranch hands.
Lambs. The lambs were screaming...
A third cowboy stretches out the lamb's neck, raises a bl knife. Just as he's about to slice its throat -
staring into the distance, shaken, still trembling from t child's shock. We see Dr. Lecter, over her shoulder, stud her intently.
They were slaughtering the spring  lambs?
Yes...! They were screaming.
So you ran away...
No. First I tried to free them... I  opened the gate of their pen - but  they wouldn't run. They just stood  there, confused. They wouldn't run...
But you could. You did.
I took one lamb. And I ran away, as  fast as I could...
a vast Montana plain, and crossing this, a tiny figure - little Clarice, holding a lamb in her arms.
Where were you going?
I don't know. I had no food or water.  It was very cold. I thought - if I  can even save just one... but he got  so heavy. So heavy...
The tiny figure stops, and after a few moments sinks to t ground, hunched over in dispair.
I didn't get more than a few miles  before the sheriff's car found me.  The rancher was so angry he sent me  to live at the Lutheran orphanage in  Bozeman. I never saw the ranch  again...
But what became of your lamb? (no response) Clarice...?
as the adult Clarice turns, staring into his feverish eye She shakes her head, unwilling - or unable - to say more.
You still wake up sometimes, don't  you? Wake up in the dark, with the  lambs screaming?
Yes...
Do you think if you saved Catherine,  you could make them stop...? Do you  think, if Catherine lives, you won't  wake up in the dark, ever again, to  the screaming of the lambs? Do you...?
Yes! I don't know...! I don't know.
(a pause; then, oddly  at peace) Thank you, Clarice.
(a whisper) Tell me his name, Dr. Lecter.
Dr. Chilton... I believe you know  each other?
as Clarice turns, startled, and the fuming Chilton seizes her elbow. Pembry and Boyle are beside him, looking grim.
Out. Let's go.
Sorry, ma'a m - we've got orders to  have you put on a place.
Clarice struggles, pulling free of them for a moment.
Brave Clarice. Will you let me know  if ever the lambs stop screaming?
(moving closer to the  bars) Yes. I'll tell you.
Promise...? (she nods. He smiles) Then why not take your case file? I  won't be needing it anymore.
He holds out the file, arm extended between the bars. She hesitates, then reaches to take it.
as the exchange is made, his index finger touches her han and lingers there, just for a moment.
widen, crackling at this touch, like sparks in a cave.
Good-bye, Clarice.
hugging the case file to her chest, stares back at him as the men crowd in on her, pushing her away.
as Dr. Lecter, head cocked in a smile, slowly recedes...

MOVING ANGLE - MR. GUMB'S POV as he pushes a rolling rack completed leather garments, each wrapped in plastic, down aisle. SOUND of many sewing machines, all clattering at o as he passes row on row of work tables. The seamstresses, mostly black or Hispanic, glance up as he passes, then qu avert their eyes, his presence disturbing them in some  nameless way. A thin FOREMAN in a flowery shirt, sees him approaching. rises from his desk and comes over cheerfully, as the rac rolls to a stop.
Hello, dear! Punctual as always. And  what have you brought us today?
He seizes one of the dangling jackets, pulling up the pla wrapper. He examines it, stroking the sleeve.
Oh, marvelous... You know, I always  say you're the Leonardo of leather.
(a harsh whisper) Oil.
Pardon...?
You're leaving oil on the skin.
The foreman quickly releases the jacket.
Of course... You'll be wanting your -

Mr. Gumb's hand reaches INTO SHOT, snatching an envelope  from him. The foreman is watching him walk away, as a  seamstress comes over to take the rack of garments. The  foreman is vaguely troubled, but shakes it off. He stroke the jacket again, admiringly.
(to seamstress) I wish we had a dozen like him...
SOUND UPCUT - Glenn Gould playing Bach's Goldberg  Variations...

Clarice, in a line of other passengers, is moving slowly  towards a departure ramp. Through a huge plate glass wind we can see her plane. She glances back over her shoulder A pair of UNIFORMED COPS brawny and impassive, their arms folded, waiting to make sure she board the flight. Clarice sighs, turning wearily back towards the jetway. T BACH CONTINUES, as we...
CLOSE ON a steaming, rather elegant dinner tray, being ca by Pembry, as he approaches Dr. Lecter's cell.
(shouts) Ready when you are, Doc!

the BACH is issuing from the cassette player. Beside it, the table, the pile of Dr. Lecter's drawings. The top one an accurate, sensitive portrait, from memory, of Clarice. Beyond the table, we see Lecter's shadowy form, seated be the paper screen. He calls out from there.
Just another minute, please!
Pembry grunts, sets the tray down. Boyle joins him, handi him a riot baton and a Mace cannister, which Pembry faste to belt clips. Boyle is similarly armed, and carries a ri of keys.
Sumbitch demanded lamb chops for  dinner, extra rare.
(laughs) What you reckon he'll want for  breakfast - some fuckin' thing from  the zoo?

Dr. Lecter sits fully clothed on the toilet - swaying  slightly, eyes closed, lost in the music, tongue working his cheek. Suddenly, like magic, a little shiny piece of  metal protrudes from his lips. He plucks it out, opens hi eyes.
he is holding the pocket clip from Prentice's disassemble pen - a straight, thin strip of metal, with a circular co at one end, a square edge at the other.

lines up his thumbnail just shy of the square edge, then  braces it against the stainless steel toilet rim. He push down, hard, using both hands for leverage. After a moment smiles, holding up the result, and twirling it before his eyes.
the straight end of the clip now forms a tiny right angle and the circular end anchors nicely between his fingers.
Pembry and Boyle turn as the toilet FLUSHES, and Dr. Lect reappears, looking jaunty.
Okay, Doc, grab some floor. Same  drill as lunchtime.
Dr. Lecter sits on the floor, legs straight, then wriggle backwards. He stretches his arms behind him, hands and wr through the bars, with two bars between them, and clasps hands.
I'm ready when you are, Officer  Pembry.
Pembry comes around the cell to squat behind Dr. Lecter. tugs his hands farther out, rather roughly, handcuffs his wrists. He shakes the cuffs, making sure of them, then no to Boyle.
as Boyle picks up the dinner tray, and Pembry crosses aro Pembry takes the keys from Boyle, unlocks the cell door, pushes it inward. Boyle goes inside with the tray.
watches as Boyle approaches the table, above five feet fr him. Boyle has to set his tray down on the floor to clear off some of the mess of drawings. The MUSIC plays on.
...Dr. Lecter's hands, outside the bars, as the makeshift key, held between the tips of his right index and middle  fingers, searches for the keyhole of the cuffs. And finds it.
as he finishes clearing the drawings, then turns back tow Dr. Lecter, stooping to pick up the tray.
is just inches from the tray when Dr. Lecter's hand darts INTO SHOT, snapping a handcuff onto his wrist.
looks up, astonished, to find himself right in the grinni face of Dr. Lecter - who just as quickly rolls sideways, snaps -
around the bolted leg of the table. And suddenly all natu SOUND and MOTION are suspended, as the MUSIC soars much  louder, each separate note of it now echoing distinctly, we see...

Pembry starting into the cell, reaching for his riot bato Dr. Lecter smashing against the cell door, driving it int Pembry, pinning him across the chest, against the door  frame... Boyle, on one knee on the floor, digging desperately in h pants pocket for his handcuff key... Pembry's hand, mashed against his body by the door, as he strains frantically to reach the baton at his waist...  Pembry's eyes, widening in horror as he stares at... Dr. Lecter's bared teeth, flashing towards him... Dr. Lecter gripping Pembry's face in his jaws, shaking it like a dog shakes a rat... Boyle finding his key, but in his terror dropping it... Dr. Lecter yanking the mace can and riot baton from the d Pembry's belt, spraying him in his bloody face, then club him to his knees... Boyle, mouth open in a silent scream, finding his key aga unlocking the handcuff, but then, as he starts to rise,  seeing... Dr. Lecter standing over him, with the riot baton raised  high; he swings it viciously down, again and again and  again... Then normal SOUND and MOTION are restored as we go to -
the cassette player, and the portrait of Clarice, both no flecked with blood. In addition to the Bach, we now hear  soft PANTING, close by, and whimpering SOBS in the backgr
eyes closed, lost in a favorite passage of the music. His bloody fingers drift airily with the notes, as his breath slows to normal. He opens his eyes, sighs contentedly, lo down.
By the sprawled legs of Boyle lie various objects that sp from his pants pocket - coins, a comb, a big pocketknife.
picks up the pocketknife, examines it happily. About a fo inch blade. He becomes aware of the WHIMPERING, off scree turns.
as he crawls, with torturous slowness, towards the comman desk, and the phone. He is crying, but frantically determ
Above the desk, hanging from pegs, are his and Boyle's  holstered revolvers...
The bronze arrow above the elevator swings towards "5," t indicates a stop there, at the top floor.
at his command desk, as he stares at the indicator. Anoth cop, JACOBS, sits on the desk's edge, flipping through a  magazine; many more cops can be seen beyond them, idling the lobby.
What is this shit...? Did somebody  go up to five? (Jacobs shakes his  head) Call Pembry, ask him what -
A GUNSHOT, and then, moments later, TWO MORE quick ones,  echo down the nearby stairwell. Sgt. Tate jumps to his fe grabs a radio mike, as the other cops stir, confused and  noisy.
(into mike) CP, shots fired on five! Repeat,  shots fires on five! Outside posts  look sharp, we've got a... Ho-ly  shit.
has begun to descend. Down to 4, then past 4...
as he reacts. The other cops, behind him, are now in a fu uproar, shouting, pulling out guns.
(to the others) SHUT UP...! Guard mount, double up  on your outside posts. Bobby, get  the vests. Rainey, Howard, cover  that fucking elevator if it comes  all the way to -
It stopped!
has, indeed, frozen at 3. Sgt. Tate lifts the microphone  again.
(into mike) Seal off a ten-block radius. Get me  the SWAT team and an ambulance, double  quick. We're going up.

HIGH ANGLE on Sgt. Tate as he leads a five-man squad, all bulletproof vests, up the stone stairs. They move fast bu carefully, covering each other from landing to landing wi drawn revolvers, shotguns. The distant Back MUSIC makes a ghostly echo in here...
A thin rectangle of light on the floor from the open elev door. We can't see inside. The MUSIC sounds closer.
approaches very cautiously, gun aimed. The other cops, be him, fan out silently to set up angles of fire, checking various office doors - all locked - as they creep up.
as he reaches the side of the elevator, hesitates, then s to point his gun inside. It's empty. He backs away.
(shouts at ceiling) Pembry? Boyle...?

ANGLE on the door, from inside, its lettering reversed on the frosted glass. The Bach is VERY LOUD. After a moment the door is shouldered open, hard enough f the glass to shatter, Tate following his gun inside, movi low, then other cops appearing behind him in the doorfram They all freeze, staring in utter horror.
Oh no... no...

is a brief snapshot from hell. The two uniformed bodies, sprawled on its back near the door, the other still in th cell, have been savaged by a knife. Blood and gore everyw The faces are unrecognizable.
struggles for control, as the other cops move grimly arou him, into the room. He pulls his walkie-talkie from his b

(into mike) Command post... Two offi- (a beat; clears his  throat) Two officers down. Prisoner is  missing. Repeat, Lecter is missing...  He's stripped the bed, might be making  a rope, check all windows. Where the  fuck is my ambulance?
a cop angrily punches OFF the music. Jacobs kneels with h fingers on Boyle's neck.
Boyle is dead, Sarge. His gun's  gone...
a cop gently removes a revolver from the bloody fist. Mur the young patrolman, brings his ear reluctantly close to gory face. A bloody bubble appears there; the wreckage GR very softly.
This one's alive!
Tate crosses, kneels to see for himself. Murray looks gre
Take ahold of him where he can feel  your hands, son. Talk to him.
What's his name, Sarge?
It's Pembry, now talk to him, God  dammit. (into radio, looking  around) Boyle's dead, Pembry's read bad.  Lecter is missing and armed - he  took Boyle's gun...
The other cop, checking the cylinder of Pembry's gun, hol up one finger to Tate.
(into radio) Pembry got off one round - there's a  chance Lecter was hit. We heard a  total of three shots fired, so he's  got four left... He's got a knife,  too.

VARIOUS ANGLES on a floodlit scene of barely controlled  pandemonium. Flashing red lights, men shouting commands,  SIRENS in the distance. SWAT members, in full gear, leap  from a black van... fan out... swarm up the steps... EMS  orderlies unload a gurney from an ambulance... Cops kneel for cover behind cars, aiming guns and rifles up at the  windows...

A trio of EMS orderlies work fast over the body, already  strapped on its gurney. They bandage a big plastic airway into place, over the butchered face, checking for a pulse the neck. Young Murray crouches, sickened, gripping a blo fist.
You're just fine, Pembry, lookin'  good, buddy, you're gonna make it...
One orderly massages the heart. Another is popping a plas bag, ready to insert the needle, when the body starts  convulsing.
Downstairs - let's go!
Quickly the gurney is elevated, wheeled out of the room,  with cops rushing forward to open the doors, help push, S men are running by in the hall, automatic rifles at the  ready...
Sgt. Tate, riding down with Jacobs, has his radio out.
(into mike) Ten-four, Lieutenant. I'm on the  elevator, bringing it down. Pembry  and Boyle are both cleared, top three  floors secured, main stairwell  secured. He's somewhere on -
A spot of blood falls on his cheek. He and Jacobs stare a each other. Another spot hits his shoulder. They look up.
Blood is dripping slowly from the corner of the service h Sgt. Tate motions for silence, as both men draw their gun
(into mike) Uh, we're pretty sure he's somewhere  on two, sir... That's all for now,  over.
The elevator doors open, and Tate and Jacobs hurry out,  stepping quickly to the side. Tate reaches back in and -
Locks the elevator into position, with its doors open. OTHER COPS are rushing up to them, curious, as Tate  frantically pushes them aside, gesturing for silence.
(whispers) He's on the roof of the elevator!

Two SWAT officers, PETERSON and KUBELL, turn a key, unloc and opening this floor's elevator doorway. The shaft is d Lying prone, they inch up to the edge, Peterson extends a mirror, on a long pole, out into the shaft.

head_text.subj: IN THE MIRROR, (DISTORTED BY THE ANGLE)

text: Is a distant figure, in a green prison jumpsuit, lying on his stomach, atop the elevator. A shiny revolver is near hand.
whispers into a radio, as Kubell carefully tips an assaul rifle, with a flashlight taped to its barrel, over the ed
I see him... There's a weapon by his  hand. He's not moving...
Can you get the drop?
We got the drop.
One warning. Then take him out.
Peterson nods to Kubell, who switches ON the flashlight, Peterson shouts down the shaft.
Quinn!! put your hands on your head!!
the green figure shows no movement.
as Peterson mutters to Kubell.
Put one in his leg.
The figure below, as Kubell's gunshot ROARS, echoing huge in the shaft, and a slug rips through the jumpsuited leg. The figure doesn't stir.
